page.title: 04WEST MEON VILLAGE
page.content: West Meon has developed in a linear fashion along the north-south and west- east roads. It lacks the traditional village green and pretty centre, but does have a variety of attractive timbered and terraced cottages. It has grown rather than been planned and at least 50% of the houses are thought to be over 60 years old. The most recent housing is a small estate built 6 years ago. There are three very small areas of council housing. The latest was built in 1959. A stone cross is situated in the middle of the village, erected by Thorold Rogers, the last surviving child of 16, as a memorial to his parents. The Church and the School are 19th century and have walls faced with knapped (i.e.squared) flints. One of the two pubs is named after Thomas Lord,founder of Lord's cricket ground.
